description: Hundreds of thousands of students have now nervously opened their A-level results. These handfuls of letter grades matter, and not just to the students themselves. They have far-reaching effects on our whole education system and public views on standards in education.
title: A-level results show the patterns of disadvantage the government must tackle

description: The new government has come to power at a time when trust in politics is, in the Labor party's words, "shattered." Keir Starmer has set out his government's aim to restore "the highest standard of integrity and honesty" in political life.
title: Gen Z has a trust problem with British institutions—especially the police

description: What will our climate look like in the future? It is hard to overstate not only the importance of answering this question, but also the challenges involved in doing so.
title: It's too hard to make business decisions in the face of climate uncertainty—here's how 'storylines' could help

description: If we want to research a subject, how do we do it? We could read about it in books or do experiments in a lab. Or another way is to find people who know something about it and ask them.
title: Aristotle, Aelian and the giant octopus: The earliest 'citizen science' goes back more than 2,000 years

description: The ancient ritual meaning of Stonehenge is still a mystery, but researchers are one step closer to understanding how the famous stone circle was created.
title: Stonehenge's 'altar stone' originally came from Scotland and not Wales, new research shows

description: During the solstices, thousands gather at Stonehenge on the Salisbury Plain in England to celebrate the monument's astronomical alignment. The focal point of these festivities is the Altar Stone—the six-ton sandstone slab that lies flat at the center of Stonehenge.
title: The Altar Stone of Stonehenge came from an unexpectedly distant place, new study reveals

description: The Niger Delta, in southern Nigeria, is one of the most significant oil-producing regions in the world. It spans over 70,000 square kilometers and is also an area of great biodiversity, including mangroves, swamps and rainforests. However, the region has been plagued by severe environmental pollution for decades, primarily due to extensive oil exploration and production activities.
title: Nigeria's Niger Delta biohazards: High radioactive levels detected

description: Good morning! Here are a few of this week's most interesting science stories to read while you're settling into the couch with your cup of General Foods International French Vanilla Cafe.
title: Saturday Citations: Citizen scientists observe fast thing; controlling rat populations; clearing nanoplastic from water

description: People who have spent time in state care as children are far less likely to go to university than their peers who have not been in care.
title: Why care leavers have no safety net when they graduate from university

description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, a majority of schools across the U.S. shifted to virtual learning. In a new study, published in Social Education Research, researchers conducted interviews with parents of students who attended middle or high schools to understand how virtual learning impacted their daily routines, stress levels, and the academic performance of the children.
title: Researchers investigate parent perceptions of virtual learning

description: A fish on land still waves its fins, but the results are markedly different when that fish is in water. Attributed to renowned computer scientist Alan Kay, the analogy is used to illustrate the power of context in illuminating questions under investigation.
title: New AI tool captures how proteins behave in context

description: Previous scientific studies have indicated that North American dog lineages were replaced with European ones between 1492 and the present day. To better understand the timing of this replacement, researchers from the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign and the University of Iowa sequenced mitochondrial DNA from archaeological dogs. Their findings suggest a complex social history of dogs during the early colonial period.
title: Ancient DNA reveals Indigenous dog lineages found at Jamestown, Virginia

description: Third-party collection of mail-in ballots has helped rural residents and those with disabilities to vote, yet the practice has become contentious and the target of laws aimed at restricting it.
title: Exposing myths about ballot collection on Native American reservations

description: Two University of Alaska Fairbanks scientists have discovered a new type of "whistler," an electromagnetic wave that carries a substantial amount of lightning energy to the Earth's magnetosphere.
title: Scientists discover phenomenon impacting Earth's radiation belts

description: For the decades since their discovery, seismic signals known as PKP precursors have challenged scientists. Regions of Earth's lower mantle scatter incoming seismic waves, which return to the surface as PKP waves at differing speeds.
title: Geophysicists find link between seismic waves called PKP precursors and strange anomalies in Earth's mantle

description: James Tour's lab at Rice University has developed a new method known as flash-within-flash Joule heating (FWF) that could transform the synthesis of high-quality solid-state materials, offering a cleaner, faster and more sustainable manufacturing process. The findings were published in Nature Chemistry on Aug. 8.
title: New twist on synthesis technique promises sustainable manufacturing

description: Researchers led by Cranfield University have developed new ways to detect sugar syrup adulteration in honey, paving the way for fast and accurate tests to discover fake products.
title: The bee's knees: New tests created to find fake honey
